title: 8 best bread bins that will keep your loaves fresh
text:
Kitchen space comes at a premium, so to earn a space on your worktop any culinary kit needs to be both functional and attractive: cue the bread bin.

Intended to keep bread fresher than just bunging it in the cupboard, a bread bin provides an airtight place to keep your baked goods while – hopefully – adding a stylish note to your kitchen.

Today, bread bins are popular in traditional materials like enamel and wood with vintage-style designs all the way up to sleek contemporary resins and on-trend metallic finishes.

With various innovations, sizes and styles you’re sure to find storage solution that works for your home from our pick below.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Eddingtons expandable bread bin: £18, A Place for Everything

This may not be the prettiest of the bread bin bunch, but this bargain piece of kit is very much worth your time. Eddingtons prides itself on being “functional but fun” and this is reflected in this multi-functional bread bin. It’s expandable and can accommodate anything from a couple of bagels when retracted up to a family-sized loaf, and is made from (BPA free) clear plastic so you can see the contents. It also features an integrated flip-down chopping-board with handy slicing guide markings and non-slip feet to prevent fingers being chopped and has an adjustable air vent for humid climates or day-old bread.

Buy now

Brabantia limited edition Patrice roll top bread bin: £44, Brabantia

Brabantia knows storage and it shows in this bread bin. With a convenient roll top – so no need to move the bread bin to extract your goods – this colourful number has a handy flat top enabling you to store canisters and your butter dish on top if needed. It’s sleek and compact but with enough space for two large-ish loaves and has a knobbly patterned base to ensure proper ventilation. We like this limited edition floral print harking back to 1969, but there are plenty of block colour or monochrome varieties to choose from if the summer of love isn’t your kitchen vibe.

Buy now

Rex London vintage apple bamboo bread bin: £39.95, Rex London

Born from a market stall on London’s Portobello Road, Rex London sources and designs quirky homewares and accessories like this vintage-style bread bin. Large enough to accommodate a loaf and some extras, this simple lidded bread bin is made from bamboo fibre, is eco-friendly and dishwasher safe. The cheery apple motif means this bin would be at home in many a country or vintage lover’s kitchen; there are lots of matching items available too, fruit fans.

Buy now

Typhoon embossed bread bin: £20.99, Wayfair

This lightweight bread bin from Typhoon is made from embossed tinware with a sustainably sourced bamboo lid. It is large enough to manage the baked goods of most families, with little counter space required as its volume is in its height. Design-wise, it has an understated geometric design and the matte white finish is hardwearing, easy to clean and will look the part in most modern, white kitchens.

Buy now

White enamel bread bin: £100, Objects of Use

This is heavier than it looks! It’s clearly a quality item and is large enough to store two loaves or more, so would be great for larger households as its shallowness means most of its space comes from the width. Made from white vitreous enamel with a classic dark blue edge, this sturdy lidded bread bin is from the Riess enamel-works in Austria which is sustainably powered by hydroelectric plants, so you can feel extra good about your purchase. The lid has tiny holes for ventilation and freshness.

Buy now

Tower black and rose gold roll top bread bin: £24.97, Amazon

This roll top bread bin from Tower’s linear range makes itself at home in millennials’ kitchens thanks to its shiny rose gold features and glossy black finish. With a convenient rolltop, this one is spacious inside yet compact – a medium loaf and something else will fit perhaps – and good for couples or small families. It’s easy to wipe down and ventilated for freshness. Also available in white with a plethora of kitchenware to coordinate, should you wish.

Buy now

Swedish bread boxes: from £14.50, Objects of Use

For something different, jump on the Scandi bandwagon with these innovative stackable boxes. Formed from untreated birch, these Swedish-made simple boxes are beautifully crafted by the visually impaired and stack neatly one above the other and interlock in doing so, finished by a grooved cutting board lid. The wood allows bread, biscuits or cake to breathe and slow the onset of staleness while adding a note of pared-down sophistication to your kitchen space. Various additional boxes and lids are available to buy: get stacking.

Buy now

Alessi black gnam bread bin: £46, Alessi

Sleek and stylish, this Alessi bread bin will be a popular choice for minimalist design fans. The eye-catching curved shape is shown off with the glossy black (or white) finish and it’s all made of thermoplastic resin. The capacity is greater than it may look and you should be able to fit a loaf and a few croissants or similar in there comfortably.

Buy now

The verdict: Bread bins

Kitchenware is always going to be a very personal choice, but the Eddingtons expandable bread bin earns its place in anyone’s kitchen thanks to its multi-use space-savvy design; pop it in the cupboard if you don’t want it on display. For out and out stylish pieces, we love the limited edition Brabantia item which can’t help but raise a smile, though it may not work in modern monochrome kitchens. The Swedish stackable bread boxes are clever, fun and functional at an accessible price point and suit most wooden kitchens.

IndyBest product reviews are unbiased, independent advice you can trust. On some occasions, we earn revenue if you click the links and buy the products, but we never allow this to bias our coverage. The reviews are compiled through a mix of expert opinion and real-world testing.
description: Keep your bread fresh with one of these tired and tested bread bins from Wayfair, Rex London, Brabantia
